Fully conjugated radical-doped COF for near-infrared photothermal conversion, C-3 thiocyanation of indoles and oxidative coupling of amines Xiaobo Li Writing – original draft Validation Investigation Conceptualization Jiajie Zhou Writing – original draft Methodology Investigation Conceptualization Wenxiu Yin Data curation Baozhen Xie Data curation Zhengfen Liu Writing – original draft Supervision Conceptualization ⁎ Jian-Jun Liu Writing – review & editing Supervision Project administration Funding acquisition ⁎ College of Chemistry and Environmental Science, Qujing Normal University, Qujing 655011, China College of Chemistry and Environmental Science Qujing Normal University Qujing 655011 China College of Chemistry and Environmental Science, Qujing Normal University, Qujing 655011, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Graphical abstract A radical-doped fully conjugated COF was rationally designed and prepared by incorporating photoactive perylenediimides into its framework, which exhibit near-infrared photothermal conversion and promote the photocatalytic C-3 thiocyanation of indoles and the oxidative coupling of amines. Radical-doped covalent organic frameworks (COFs) have received much interest as it confers additional functions such as photomodulated electrical conductivity, magnetism, and photochromism. Such COFs are relatively underexplored, however, mainly due to the lack of suitable highly photoactive building blocks. Herein, a rare radical-doped fully conjugated COF (PDI-COF) was rationally designed and prepared by incorporating photoactive perylenediimides (PDIs) into its framework. Characterization of the product PDI-COF not only confirmed its porous and stable skeleton, but also revealed the radical derived from photoinduced electron transfer between the PDI and electron donor. The fully conjugated and radical-doped characteristics enable the effective realization of near-infrared photothermal conversion in this COF. Moreover, this radical-doped COF can efficiently generate superoxide radical anions under light irradiation, which promote the photocatalytic C-3 thiocyanation of indoles and the oxidative coupling of amines in high yield and good recyclability at room temperature and without additives. This study demonstrates that introducing a photoactive organic dye into a COF is an effective approach to photothermal conversion materials and metal-free porous photocatalysts for application in photothermal therapy and photocatalytic organic synthesis. Keywords Covalent organic frameworks Photothermal conversion Radical-doped Organic synthesis Photocatalysis Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The use of novel and efficient visible light-driven photocatalysts for organic conversion has attracted significant attention in recent years, and is critical for the development of environmentally benign and sustainable methods in chemical synthesis [1–6]. Covalent organic frameworks (COFs), an emerging class of ordered crystalline materials built from organic building blocks, are an increasing focus of research owing to their tunable optoelectronic properties, porosities, and large specific surface areas [7,8]. In addition to their applications in proton conduction, semiconductors, gas separation and storage, and electrode materials, efforts have been made to expand the potential of COFs as organic or photocatalysts owing to their abundant and accessible active sites, and robust chemical and thermal stabilities [9–12]. The holes and electrons photogenerated under visible light irradiation of COF materials can trigger a variety of reactions, such as oxygen evolution, hydrogen generation, carbon dioxide reduction, and organic synthetic transformations [13–16]. To further improve the photocatalytic activity of COF materials, a fast and long-lived charge separation state, enhanced light absorption, and a suitable bandgap are crucial requirements. These factors are dependent on the intrinsic properties of the chemical monomers of the COF material [17]. The fabrication of fully conjugated COF materials would achieve adequate light absorption as well as a fast and long-lived charge separation state [18,19]. Only very recently, fully conjugated COFs have been constructed and used in supercapacitors, lithium-ion batteries, and fluorescence devices [20–23]. However, few studies have explored the photocatalytic organic synthesis potential of fully conjugated COFs. Han’s group reported a fully conjugated sp2 carbon COF that facilitates impressive photocatalytic oxidative organic transformations [24]. Wang and co-workers introduced 1,2,4-thiadiazole into a pyrene-based COF, which exhibits excellent photocatalytic activity for oxidative amine coupling and thioamide cyclization [25]. Despite the progress toward photocatalytic fully conjugated COF materials, significant challenges limit their application. The selection of appropriate functional building blocks and achieving long-range order through crystallization are significant barriers to practical photocatalytic processes. Perylenediimides (PDIs), a class of strong visible light-absorbing organic dyes with π electron-deficient planes, could provide a tunable platform to design efficient photocatalytic systems based on crystalline COF materials [26–31]. PDIs have recently been shown to produce radical anions (PDI•−) by photoinduced electron transfer, therefore exhibiting photochromism [32]. Moreover, PDI•− shows typical redshift absorption to the near infrared region. These useful near infrared absorbers play a vital role as photothermal materials for photothermal therapy. In addition, PDIs in homogeneous or heterogeneous systems can accumulate enough energy via consecutive visible light excitations to reduce stable aryl halides to aryl radicals [33,34]. However, the difficult stabilization of PDI•− formed by photoinduced electron transfer has limited research into photothermal conversion and photocatalytic properties. Matile’s group introduced chiral centers and sulfones into the imide and PDI core positions, which resulted in good asymmetric anion–π catalysis with 96 % enantioselectivity [35]. Zhu’s group reported a PDI/TiO2 composite photocatalyst showing impressive visible light-driven photocatalytic activity toward phenol degradation [36]. Recently, Lin and coworkers synthesized a series of PDI-based hybrid heterostructures with halogen substituents at bay positions, which exhibited enhanced photocatalytic oxidation of mustard gas simulants [37]. Despite this promising precedent, almost no PDI-based COF materials have been reported because intrinsic insolubility and relatively poor crystallinity hinder their synthesis and photocatalytic properties. Herein, we report the design and synthesis of a COF using typical electron-deficient PDIs and a triazine ring monomer to form a fully conjugated structure in a crystalline framework, named PDI-COF. The obtained PDI-COF material exhibits high photostability and the rare radical-doped property that the radical anion (PDI•−) signal can be observed by ESR spectroscopy. Benefiting from the fully conjugated framework and photoinduced PDI•− radicals, this PDI-COF material demonstrates effective near-infrared photothermal conversion and excellent photocatalysis of the C-3 thiocyanation of indoles and the oxidative coupling of amines. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis of perylenediimide-based covalent organic framework (PDI-COF) A Teflon-lined steel autoclave (15 mL) was charged with perylene dianhydride (58.84 mg, 0.15 mmol), 4,4′,4′'-(1,3,5-triazine-2,4,6-triyl)trianiline (TTTA) (35.44 mg, 0.1 mmol), N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP) (2 mL), mesitylene (0.5 mL), and isoquinoline (10 uL). The mixture was stirred under nitrogen for 5 min to achieve a homogenous dispersion, and imidazole (5 g) was added. The autoclave was degassed by bubbling nitrogen for 5 min, was sealed and was heated at 180 °C for 3 days. After cooling to room temperature, the resulting precipitate was filtered and washed sequentially with NMP, EtOH and THF. The sample was further subjected to Soxhlet extraction in CH2Cl2, THF, and acetone for 48 h. Finally, the samples were dried under vacuum to obtain PDI-COF as a dark red powder in a yield of approximately 85 %. 3 Results and discussions 3.1 Synthesis and characterizations of PDI-COF To build the fully conjugated radical-doped PDI-based COF, rational selection of the monomer is vital to enable near-infrared photothermal conversion and photocatalysis. Here, 4,4′,4′’-(1,3,5-triazine-2,4,6-triyl)trianiline (TTTA) was utilized as the COF framework building block because the triazine groups were expected to reversibly form radical cations upon irradiation. The synthetic procedure for PDI-COF is illustrated in Fig. 1 a. PDI-COF was obtained by a polycondensation reaction between the monomer 3,4,9,10-perylenetetracarboxylic dianhydride (PDA) and TTTA in NMP/imidazole/ mesitylene under isoquinoline catalysis at 180 °C for 3 days. The PDI-COF was obtained as dark red powder in yields up to 85 %. The chemical structure of PDI-COF was first demonstrated by FTIR. Compared with the corresponding monomers, new characteristic bands for PDI-COF appeared at 1706 and 1349 cm−1, attributed to symmetric vibration of the imide −C = O group and stretching vibration of −C-N-C of the six-membered imide rings (Fig. 1b). The characteristic −C = O band at 1770 cm−1 for anhydride PDA, and that for the TTTA amino group at 3325 cm−1, were not detected in PDI-COF (Figure S7). In the solid-state 13C NMR spectrum, PDI-COF shows a broad peak with several close shoulders at 115–140 ppm corresponding to overlapping signals of the benzene rings and C-N groups, and two split peaks at 162–175 ppm corresponding to the carbonyl group (Fig. 1c). These results indicate the successful formation of the imide linkage in PDI-COF from the condensation between the TTTA amines and PDA anhydride function, indicating the polycondensation of the starting reagents. The crystalline structure of PDI-COF was examined by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD), revealing diffraction peaks at 2.27°, 3.46°, 3.91°, and 5.03°, corresponding to the (100), (110), (200), and (210) facets, respectively, and reflecting its well-ordered crystalline structure (Fig. 2 a). The hexagonal framework of PDI-COF was simulated by Material Studio to obtain the optimum structure. Among various possible stacking modes, the AA stacking mode in space group P63/m agrees well with the experimental PXRD data (R wp = 4.08 %, R P = 3.09 %) with negligible difference and calculated lattice parameters a = b = 44.25 Å, c = 4.11 Å, α = β = 90°, γ = 120° (Fig. 2b and Figure S3). The porosity of PDI-COF was determined using nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherms (Fig. 2c). According to IUPAC classification, the adsorption–desorption curve of PDI-COF represents a type II isotherm with a Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area value of 716 m2·g−1, illustrating its mesoporous nature. Meanwhile, the pore size distribution of PDI-COF was evaluated to be 3.7 nm, consistent with the pore diameter (3.7 nm) predicted from the proposed AA stacking mode. The morphology and precise microstructure of PDI-COF were further investigated by scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM). According to SEM, the PDI-COF has a micron-scale stacked pancake structure, revealing a two-dimensional network (Fig. 2d). High resolution TEM reveals an interlayer spacing of 4.10 nm, which is close to the interlayer spacing of predicted stacking mode parameters (Fig. 2e). PDI-based compounds are photoactive and can undergo reversible photoinduced electron transfer to form a radical anion [38]. As expected, the photoinduced radical anion in PDI-COF was directly confirmed by electron spin resonance (ESR) measurements. As shown in Fig. 2f, the ESR spectra of PDI-COF showed a weak signal before irradiation, and a relatively strong and sharp radical signal after irradiation, indicating that the material will rapidly produce PDI radical anions (PDI-COF•−) upon irradiation by UV–Vis light. However, compared with the reported photochromic PDI materials, the color change of PDI-COF has not been observed [32]. Regarding the weak signal seen without irradiation, owing to photoinduced electron transfer between DMF and the PDI moieties, PDI radical anions may form under indoor natural light (TGA revealed a small amount of DMF solvent in PDI-COF, Figure S6)[39,40]. In other words, PDI-COF is radical-doped COF material showing a clear ESR signal without irradiation, characteristic of PDI radical anions present in the dark red crystalline solid. 3.2 Optical and electronic properties of PDI-COF The thermal stability of PDI-COF was characterized by thermogravimetric analysis (TGA). The TGA curve measured under N2 atmosphere indicates < 3 % weight loss under 150 °C, attributed to residual solvent. Almost no further weight loss is observed until molecular decomposition at ∼ 450 °C (Figure S6). The solid-state UV–Vis diffuse reflectance spectrum of PDI-COF shows a broad absorption band at 400–650 nm, attributed to the π–π* transition of the PDI and TTTA. Based on the Kubelka-Munk function, the corresponding optical band energy of PDI-COF is estimated to be 1.84 eV, indicating semiconductor-like characteristics (Fig. 3 a). To determine the position of the conduction band of PDI-COF, Mott-Schottky analysis was carried out at frequencies of 1500, 2000, and 3000 Hz (Fig. 3b). The results illustrate a positive slope indicative of n-type semiconductor behavior. Therefore, the conduction band position was determined to be −0.53 V (vs. NHE, pH = 7), which indicates that PDI-COF can thermodynamically reduce O2 to superoxide radical O2 •− (O2/O2 •− = −0.33 V, vs. NHE). The valence band position was determined from valence band X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (VB-XPS), revealing a valence band edge at 1.36 eV (Figure S9). Based on the conduction and valence band values, the band gap of PDI-COF is calculated to be 1.89 eV, which is close to the optical band gap and suitable for photocatalytic formation of superoxide radical O2 •− intermediates (Fig. 3c). The transient photocurrent response demonstrates that PDI-COF shows high separation and transfer efficiency of photogenerated charges under both O2 and N2 atmospheres (Fig. 3d). The photogenerated charge of the PDI-COF under O2 atmosphere is lower than that under N2, which may be due to quenching of photogenerated electrons by O2 and the formation of superoxide radical O2 •−. In addition, the impedance experiments in both dark and 100 W white LED irradiation were performed. The results showed that the impedance of PDI-COF decreases under the condition of 100 W white LED irradiation (Figure S11). 3.3 Photothermal conversion of PDI-COF PDI-COF is radical-doped COF material showing a clear ESR signal and good light absorption properties in the near-infrared region (Fig. 2f and Figure S8), which prompted us to evaluate its photothermal conversion performance by monitoring the temperature variation of the catalyst surface under near-infrared light irradiation. Under near-infrared laser irradiation (808 nm, 0.4 W cm−2), PDI-COF shows a prominent temperature increase, which can be recorded with an IR camera (Fig. 4 b). The surface temperature increased sharply increased to 129.4 °C within 100 s (ΔT max = 99.9 °C) (Fig. 4a). In comparison, the temperature of blank quartz glass rose only 4.8 °C under these conditions. Hence, PDI-COF presents strong photothermal conversion performance. Moreover, the photothermal effect of PDI-COF is linearly dependent on the near-infrared laser power from 0.10 to 0.5 W cm−2, indicative of a thermal control performance (Fig. 4c). In addition, the cycling test results also indicate that outstanding photostability of PDI-COF, as evidenced by the almost consistent photothermal conversion efficiency observed even after five repetitions (Fig. 4d). Based on the photothermal conversion and light absorption results, the photothermal performance can be attributed to both original PDI-COF and its radical anions (PDI-COF•−), which effectively achieve photothermal conversion due to the fully conjugated structure and strong light absorption of PDI-COF•−. To our knowledge, this is the first time that radical-doped COF has been directly applied to near-infrared photothermal conversion without additional chemical modifications [41,42]. 3.4 The photocatalytic performance of PDI-COF Substituted indoles are an essential class of intermediates that find extensive applications in the synthesis of agrochemicals, alkaloids, and drug candidates [43]. Numerous researchers have been dedicated to the thiocyanation of the C–H bond at the C-3 position of indoles, with Guipeng Yu group's work being particularly noteworthy [44]. To ascertain whether our rationally designed PDI-COF catalyst also effectively promotes the thiocyanation of the C–H bond at the C-3 position of indoles, we have conducted the following investigations (Table 1 ). In preliminary optimization experiments, we selected indole 1a and NH4SCN as the substrates for the reaction, THF as the solvent, and 3 mol% PDI-COF as the catalyst, and exposed the mixture to a 100 W white light lamp (400–750 nm) under air atmosphere for 48 h. We were delighted to observe the desired product 3a in 56 % yield. In control experiments in the absence of catalyst or irradiation, only 12 % or trace yields of 3a were obtained (Table 1, entries 2–3), confirming PDI-COF to be an effective photocatalyst. Replacing THF with toluene, acetone, CH3CN, or DMF failed to improve the yield of 3a (Table 1, entries 4–7). However, increasing the loading of PDI-COF from 3 to 15 mol% provided product 3a in an excellent isolated yield of 97 % (Table 1, entries 8–9). Finally, the yield of compound 3a decreased when the reaction time and the amount of solvent were reduced (Table 1, entries 10–11). Therefore, the optimal conditions (Table 1, entry 9) were selected for further exploration. Applying the optimal thiocyanation conditions, the indole substrate scope was evaluated next (Table 2 ). Unsubstituted indole provided C-3 thiocyanated product 3a in 97 % yield. Substitution at the indole C-2 position by methyl (1b) and phenyl (1c) provided excellent 92 % and 99 % yields of products 3b and 3c, respectively. C-4 substitution with methyl and aldehyde groups gave the expected compounds 3d and 3e in 98 % and 95 % yields, respectively. Substitution at the indole C-5 position was also well tolerated, giving the methyl- and methoxy-substituted thiocyanation products 3f and 3 g in yields of 94 % and 97 %, respectively. Substitution at the C-6 position with electron-donating (–CH3) and electron-withdrawing (−F, −Cl, Br) groups provided products 3 h-3 k in yields ranging from 34 to 97 %. We conducted individual analyses of the yields of products 3i, 3j, and 3 k. The medium yield was observed when F replaced 3i, while a high yield was achieved with Cl replacing 3j. Only 34 % yield was obtained when bromine replaced 3 k. This result may be due to the activity of the halogens. In addition, the corresponding radical intermediates were produced during the reaction process, where different halogens have different effects on the stability of the radical intermediates. Notably, the thiocyanation product 3 l was also obtained in 93 % yield when N-methylindole was used in the reaction. To demonstrate the potential to scale up the PDI-COF photocatalysis, a gram scale reaction using 7 mmol of indole successfully furnished 1.16 g of product 3a in 95 % yield. Moreover, the PDI-COF photocatalyst has a high recyclability, maintaining yields over 90 % after three cycles (Figure S10), and further demonstrating the high photostability of the PDI-COF during photocatalysis. To expand the scope of organic transformations, and motivated by the excellent results for indole thiocyanation, we applied the PDI-COF catalyst to the oxidative coupling of amines. A preliminary optimization of the reaction conditions is detailed in Table 3 . In a preliminary control experiment in the absence of PDI-COF, using p-fluorobenzylamine 4a as the substrate, DMF as the solvent, and a 100 W white LED light (400–750 nm) source for 48 h at room temperature, the desired product 5a was obtained in only 11 % yield (Table 3, entry 1). Use of only 0.2 mol% of PDI-COF without irradiation also, unsurprisingly, gave the product in very low yield (Table 3, entry 2). However, simultaneous use of PDI-COF catalyst and the light source successfully provided the oxidative coupling product 5a in isolated yields up to 99 % (Table 3, entry 3). The excellent yield of product 5a was maintained after only 12 h of reaction, but decreased to 47 % after only 6 h (Table 3, entries 4–6). Replacing DMF solvent with CH3CN, EtOH, THF, acetone or toluene, were detrimental to the conversion, with yields of product 5a ranging from 11 to 35 % (Table 3, entries 7–11). Finally, reductions in catalyst loading or solvent volume were also unfavorable for the yield of product 5a (Table 3, entries 12–13). Hence, optimal reaction conditions for the oxidative coupling of amines are represented in Table 3, entry 5. With optimal amine oxidative coupling conditions in hand, the amines substrate scope was evaluated with substituted benzylamines (Table 4 ). p-fluorobenzylamine has already been investigated in the optimisation of the reaction conditions, and then o- and m-fluorobenzylamine were selected for testing, which showed that the corresponding oxidative coupling products 5b and 5c could be obtained in 86 % and 50 % yields, respectively. In addition, the desired products 5d, 5e and 5f were obtained in 84 %, 65 % and 50 % yields, respectively, when p-chlorobenzylamine, o-chlorobenzylamine and m-chlorobenzylamine were used for oxidative coupling studies. Subsequently, the products 5 g-5i were obtained with yields ranging from 54 % to 71 % when the reactions were conducted using benzylamine substituted with an electron-donating group –OCH3 in para-, ortho-and meso-positions. When benzylamine lacked any substituent group, the yield of 80 % for the product 5j was achieved. Finally, employing thiophen-2-ylmethanamine as the substrate resulted in a 57 % yield for the product 5 k. It is worth noting that, upon a comprehensive analysis of the research findings mentioned above, it becomes evident that PDI-COF exhibits significantly superior catalytic reaction efficacy towards para-substituted benzylamine as compared to ortho-substituted and meso-substituted benzylamine. This could be attributed to the fact that the intermediates formed by para-substituted benzylamine are more stable throughout the course of the reaction. In addition, we attempted two experiments. In the first, no oxidative coupling reaction of aniline was observed, and in the second, a significantly low yield of the oxidative coupling product of the alkylamine substrate (heptanamine) was obtained, resulting in unsatisfactory outcomes. Nevertheless, these experimental findings have provided crucial insights for our subsequent mechanistic investigations. To demonstrate the practicality of the PDI-COF catalyzed oxidative coupling of amines, we carried out a gram-scale reaction with 6 mmol p-fluorobenzylamine, obtaining 1.25 g of product 5a in 90 % yield. 3.5 Study on reaction mechanisms Based on the experimental results for the PDI-COF catalyzed C-3 thiocyanation of indoles and oxidative coupling of amines, and a review of the relevant literature [45–47], two plausible reaction mechanisms are proposed (Scheme 1 ). Initially, photocatalyst PDI-COF in the ground state was excited to the higher energy state [PDI-COF]* when exposed to light. A single-electron-transfer (SET) process between [PDI-COF]* and SCN- generated [PDI-COF]•− radical anion and SCN•. Subsequently, [PDI-COF]•− underwent another SET process with O2, returning it to its ground state PDI-COF while producing O2 •−, This initiated the subsequent catalytic cycle. The SCN• radical proceeded to radical addition with indole 1a to form an unstable carbon radical intermediate A, which was rapidly oxidized by O2 •− to the carbon cation intermediate B. Finally, re-aromatization of intermediate B through loss of a proton gave product 3-thiocyanoindole 3a. In the oxidative coupling of amines, [PDI-COF]* in its excited state performed a SET process with benzylamine 4a to provide the radical cationic intermediate C and [PDI-COF]•−. Subsequently, [PDI-COF]•− experienced another SET process with O2, returning it to its ground state of PDI-COF while generating O2 •−, which triggered the subsequent photocatalytic cycle. Radical cationic intermediate C then interacted with O2 •−, leading to protonated intermediate D and HO2 –. Removal of H2O2 provided neutral intermediate E which can couple with benzylamine, eliminating an NH3 molecule in a condensation reaction to yield the final oxidative coupling product 5j. It is evident that the C-3 thiocyanation of indoles and the oxidative coupling reaction of amines have similarities in their reaction mechanisms. 4 Conclusions In summary, a rare radical-doped and fully conjugated COF based on perylenediimides (PDIs) and triazine was designed and prepared with high crystallinity. The incorporation of PDI into the skeleton improves the visible light absorption and the rapid separation of photogenerated charge in the PDI-COF. The fully conjugated PDI-COF material shows photogeneration of stable charge-separated states, which enables effective near-infrared photothermal conversion. Moreover, this COF can produce superoxide radical anions under light irradiation for efficient photocatalytic C-3 thiocyanation of indoles and oxidative coupling of amines, with excellent substrate scope, high yield, good recyclability at room temperature and without additives. This work demonstrates that incorporation of a photoactive organic dye into COFs is an effective approach to photothermal conversion materials and metal-free porous photocatalysts for application in photothermal therapy and photocatalytic organic transformations. coredata.dc:description: Radical-doped covalent organic frameworks (COFs) have received much interest as it confers additional functions such as photomodulated electrical conductivity, magnetism, and photochromism. Such COFs are relatively underexplored, however, mainly due to the lack of suitable highly photoactive building blocks. Herein, a rare radical-doped fully conjugated COF (PDI-COF) was rationally designed and prepared by incorporating photoactive perylenediimides (PDIs) into its framework. Characterization of the product PDI-COF not only confirmed its porous and stable skeleton, but also revealed the radical derived from photoinduced electron transfer between the PDI and electron donor. The fully conjugated and radical-doped characteristics enable the effective realization of near-infrared photothermal conversion in this COF. Moreover, this radical-doped COF can efficiently generate superoxide radical anions under light irradiation, which promote the photocatalytic C-3 thiocyanation of indoles and the oxidative coupling of amines in high yield and good recyclability at room temperature and without additives. This study demonstrates that introducing a photoactive organic dye into a COF is an effective approach to photothermal conversion materials and metal-free porous photocatalysts for application in photothermal therapy and photocatalytic organic synthesis.
